sect2.title: Accessibility
sect2.para: Support for people with disabilities has been a key focus for GNOME, so successive releases have included increasing support for accessibility. GNOME &version; improves this framework, and its tools, to create a better experience for existing users, and to make the desktop available to new groups of users.

sect3.title: Keyboard Accessibility Status
sect3.para:
As mentioned in the accessibility section, the new Keyboard Accessibility Status gives quick access to the Accessibility control panel, and gives visual feedback when using the sticky-keys feature. The sticky-keys feature allows people with limited mobility to press modifier keys, such as shift, in sequence instead of simultaneously. TODO: Remove the duplication?

sect3.title: Screen Reader and Magnifier
sect3.para:
The Gnopernicus screen reader and magnifier has some new features in GNOME &version;.
TODO: rewrite this based on email asking for explanation: For instance, the magnifier can now track the mouse and focus in either proportional, centered or push modes. The crosshair is rather useful for users with specific visual disabilities.
Blind users will appreciate the "watch any widget" feature as well as the "describe my surroundings" feature. A very versatile presentation scheme based on role events and devices exist, and it would fulfill the most sophisticated needs, including support for multi-layered numerical keypad control.

sect3.title: Dasher
sect3.para:
Dasher is a predictive input system that should be particularly useful to people with severe disabilities. At the moment, it allows text entry, but future versions should allow complete control of the desktop.
